Orson Welles.Action: Mother's final words instill a hopeful dream and purpose in young Orson; he responds with solemn attention and wonder.
Blows out his birthday candles with determination after his mother's advice about having a great dream, symbolizing his early confidence and ambition.
Portrayed as a confident young man, 'Boy Wonder' in Hollywood at age 24, suggesting early recognition of his skill and capability.
Appears uncomfortable in his own body despite vast passions and appetites.
Tears through life with incendiary energy; described as inspiring and ferocious, visionary and coldly ambitious; part artist, part fraud, all showman.
Barreled in and took over the rehearsal, showing dominant and forceful behavior.
Rejected classical costume sketches for JULIUS CAESAR, indicating strong artistic vision but possible intolerance of others' ideas.
Directed productions that stunned the sedate elite and included diverse casting (MACBETH with an entirely colored cast).
Expresses contrition at press conference, saying he never meant to cause panic and feels horrible about it.
Laughs explosively in taxi after expressing contrition publicly.
Becomes the voice of 'The Shadow' and rapidly gains prominence on radio, showing skill and confidence in performance and direction.
Creates and directs the 'War of the Worlds' broadcast, which becomes the most famous radio show in history, demonstrating creativity and impact.
Holds a press conference taking responsibility for the unintended panic, showing awareness but somewhat reactive rather than proactive management of the situation.
Explodes with laughter after the press conference despite expressing contrition publicly, indicating possible lack of seriousness or poor judgment in handling the crisis.
Laughs with female extras in the commissary; charmingly tours Hollywood studios and nightclubs; charmed rival gossip columnists Louella Parsons and Hedda Hopper.
Poses proudly in front of his Brentwood home; widely tours the studio and town showing confidence, but no indication of genuine connection beyond surface charm.
Charms his way through Hollywood, meeting major figures and earning admiration from influential gossip columnists like Louella Parsons and Hedda Hopper.
Spends considerable time socializing in nightclubs and focusing on his image around Hollywood rather than immediate work-related tasks.
Smiles mischievously and likens Hollywood work to the best electric train set a boy ever had
Blissfully tours RKO facilities, showing enthusiasm and charm; prepares to dazzle with his first feature; confidently addresses microphone with a mischievous smile.
His work is doubted and disparaged by powerful industry figures like Louis B. Mayer who believe he will fail and never complete a picture.
Flourishes a cigarette and coin, perfecting a magic trick in the presence of Mankiewicz, maintaining an elegant and impressive demeanor.
Responds to Mank's criticism with frustration but engages in the conversation without hostility.
Makes the cigarette pass through the coin trick, calls it 'Magic' happily.
Laughs and goes to Mank in the bathroom; ties Mank's bow tie for him.
Expresses desire for compassion and insight in dissecting their movie subject.
Smiles confidently at himself in the mirror preparing for confrontation with Hearst.
Performs an astounding bit of slight of hand, making a cigarette pass through a coin.
Confidently smiles at himself in the mirror and rehearses the introduction 'How do you do, Mr. Hearst? My name is Orson Welles.'
Proposes to Mank that they find the man and dissect him with compassion and insight to create their movie biography.
Engages in casual conversation with Mank about Howard Hughes, showing a playful curiosity.
Sits quietly at the table with Mank among distinguished guests without dominating the scene.
Proposes an idea to do a film about Howard Hughes, showing creative initiative.
Asks Mank about the dangers of Howard Hughes after Mank warns aggressively, showing a willingness to seek information before acting.
Rapaciously devours his dinner while others share a lighthearted story, showing little engagement with group warmth.
Flourishes his napkin like a bullfighter's cape in a playful, inspired manner, contributing to the lively atmosphere.
Suddenly inspired, confidently introduces a new creative idea (Manolete) despite prior setbacks.
Demonstrates knowledge of theatrical traditions and uses metaphor (bullfighter's cape) skillfully to support his idea.
Engages in confident, playful banter, showing intellectual agility and social ease.
Smiles across the table, tells an engaging and humorous story, creates laughter at the table.
Uses playful banter and nicknames among companions (e.g. calling Mank 'factotum, ally and comrade-in-arms'), fostering friendly atmosphere.
Uses humor, storytelling, and theatrical demonstration to captivate and engage an audience.
Interacts confidently with notable contemporaries, commanding attention and respect.
Displays imaginative skill in dramatizing personal anecdotes to entertain.
Engages the group with a lively and humorous bullfighting story, entertaining and eliciting laughter and applause.
Speaks up against Hearst's condemnation of bullfighting despite nervous atmosphere and warning from Mank, showing courage but also creating discomfort.
Maintains composure and polite but guarded responses during tense questioning by Hearst, refraining from hostility despite Hearst's cold stare.
Performs an impressive and confident bullfighting story demonstration capturing attention and applause.
Responds to Hearst's accusation about cruelty to animals with a culturally nuanced, confident reply, defending the tradition in Spain.
Fails to evade the tense situation after Hearst's cold stare and the silence that follows, showing a lack of social tact or strategic self-restraint.
Clearly admits he has not made any pictures yet when questioned by Hearst, showing honesty but also exposing his lack of prior experience.
Observes Hearst closely and critiques his hypocrisy quietly with a friend.
Described by others as 'a real piece of work' but 'deep down, he's a good kid.'
Mentioned indirectly without direct friendly or hostile interaction; presence noted but little personal engagement shown.
Is described by others as 'a real piece of work' and 'a caution,' indicating a notable and memorable personality, but no direct demonstration of skill or intelligence in this excerpt.
Is acknowledged as 'deep down, he's a good kid,' suggesting a positive personal trait but not necessarily competence.
Wanders the impressive ballroom with Mank, taking in surroundings, showing awareness but no active, skillful engagement.
Engages with others, recites poetry, observes people thoughtfully during a social event.
Dances with Carole Lombard and participates in light-hearted conversation, shares a self-deprecating joke about fear of failure.
Responds to Carole Lombard's bluntness with a playful, mild reproof rather than anger.
Shows compassion by commenting 'That poor woman' about Marion, recognizing her distress.
Observes Hearst alone on the dance floor, implying awareness of others' isolation.
Withdraws from social setting, wandering alone in hallways, indicating introspection but possible social detachment.
Responds to Carole Lombard's bluntness with wit and a composed demeanor.
Shows awareness and empathy observing Marion and Hearst's interaction, recognizing the complexity of Marion's situation.
Leaves his suite and roams the hallways seemingly lost in thought or contemplation.
Roams the hallways and studies the environment thoughtfully, showing curiosity and imaginative association (comparing the castle to Xanadu).
Smiles knowingly while observing Hearst and Marion dance, indicating insight and strategic emotional understanding.
Paces by the pool, puffing on a cigar and scribbling notes, showing focused and active engagement in his work.
Roars energetically at Mank and demands attention, demonstrating confident leadership and drive.
Has a sudden burst of inspiration and expresses total confidence in the idea for the project.
Enthusiastically shares his vision about exposing a powerful public figure, showing excitement and creative drive.
Persists in pushing the controversial idea despite Mank's discomfort and warnings, ignoring his friend's strong objections.
Envisions a bold, ambitious project by identifying a powerful subject and its cinematic potential.
Insists on pursuing a legally risky portrayal despite warnings about the dangerous power of the target.
Persists confidently in his vision even when an experienced colleague advises caution due to potential deadly consequences.
Engages in a verbally abusive, aggressive confrontation with Mank, insults him, and shoves him violently into a pool.
Engages confidently and aggressively with Mank, verbally attacking and pursuing him around the pool, showing determination and boldness.
Uses sharp, insightful criticism about Mank's fall from grace in the film industry, demonstrating perceptiveness and knowledge.
Shoves Mank violently, losing control physically and escalating the conflict.
Shoves Mank violently, blocking his exit from the pool.
Offers Mank a job and a chance to be himself again, despite Mank's self-doubt and drinking problems.
Passionately insists that Mank's creative potential is not over and that they must work together.
Shoves Mank violently into the pool, asserting dominance and control.
Confronts Mank with a forceful and confident ultimatum to reclaim his creativity.
Demonstrates emotional intelligence and persuasion by kneeling and appealing deeply to Mank's potential and their shared opportunity.
Displays intense determination and ability to inspire others despite Mank's resistance and self-doubt.
Engages deeply and playfully with Mank, acting out scenes and laughing during creative collaboration.
Has a ferocious argument with Mank, leading to Mank storming out and slamming the door.
After argument, stands alone quietly, reflecting on himself in the mirror.
Deep in thought, reflects silently, showing introspection and self-awareness.
Engages in fearless acting and writing, emoting and laughing with creative energy.
Leaps from character to character during creative process without hesitation.
Engages in a ferocious argument with Mank, escalating to shouting and door slamming.
Engages in a reflective, thoughtful conversation with Mank about complex human emotions and motivations, including empathy towards Hearst's condition.
Sends a telegram encouraging Mank to stop drinking and to start writing, ending with a sign of affection 'Love you madly, Orson.'
Sends encouraging and concise telegrams to Mank urging him to start writing and stop drinking
Signs telegram with 'Love you madly,' showing personal support and confidence in the project
Applies considerable charm to Hollywood gossip columnists Hedda Hopper and Louella Parsons, engaging them amicably.
Dresses differently for each encounter, indicating adaptability and attentiveness.
Studies elaborate set models carefully, imagining his movie on an enormous sound stage, demonstrating preparation and vision.
Uses considerable charm to navigate between powerful gossip columnists Hedda Hopper and Louella Parsons, effectively managing social dynamics.
Questions a top cinematographer about working with him despite being a newcomer, showing self-awareness and humility.
Explains his vision of filming 'life -- in all its joyous complexity' and uses a magic trick to engage Hedda and illustrate truth behind illusion.
Sighs quietly in response to Hedda's teasing about his love life, showing a vulnerable, human side.
Explains complex concepts about truth and illusion in movies with confidence and clarity, using a magic trick to illustrate his point.
Persuades Hedda by making the quarter disappear and reappear, charming her and effectively communicating his artistic vision.
Uses creative methods (magic trick) to communicate innovative ideas about film, showing skill and imaginative competence.
Sighs quietly and avoids directly addressing Hedda's question about Dolores Del Rio, showing potential discomfort or avoidance.
Leans forward to light Louella's cigarette.
Leaps up and embraces Mank after reading the screenplay.
Refuses to do Hearst character, despite pressure.
Encourages Mank positively, insists he must never doubt him again.
Hands drinks around for a toast, inclusive gesture.
Critiques the script and title with high fervor and intensity, but no apparent harshness.
Confidently encourages Mankiewicz and insists he must never be doubted again.
Recognizes the need to improve and shape the script, indicating discernment and skill.
Rejects the original publisher's name and proposes a strong, effective alternative title 'Kane' showing creative judgment.
Leads a celebratory toast and confidently engages his collaborators, fostering team morale.
Works intensely on script revisions, discarding large portions to refine the work, demonstrating commitment and skill.
Reacts with recoil and tells Mank to get away when confronted, avoiding direct engagement.
Bats away the script and refuses to acknowledge Mank's grievance, insisting ownership and control with harsh words.
Tells Mank he can do anything he wants with the script and slams the door, ending the conversation abruptly.
Assertively claims ownership of script and control over production, showing confidence and decisiveness.
Takes a moment of silence alone after confrontation, possibly reflecting or calming himself.
Paces with combustible energy and discusses title ideas enthusiastically without dismissing others' suggestions.
Responds theatrically and somewhat defensively about budget constraints, showing frustration.
Earnestly appeals to Schaefer to let him make the movie "KANE," expressing personal need and sincerity despite pressure to choose the safer option.
Shows humility and respects Schaefer's authority, quietly accepting the decision to proceed without argument and responding with a genuine smile.
Refuses the safer, more commercially assured project WAR OF THE WORLDS to passionately insist on making KANE, showing confidence in his vision despite pressure.
Speaks honestly and humbly about not knowing exactly why he must make this movie, showing emotional awareness but some uncertainty.
Accepts the decision to proceed with his film making without pushing or arguing further, showing composure and professional restraint.
Does not say thank you to Schaefer despite prompting, simply smiles and leaves.
Surveys his sound stage and savoring the moment, rehearses an inspiring speech including collective words like 'Together we will…', 'Following our lead...'
Stands confidently alone in a massive sound stage, savoring the moment and surveying his domain before rehearsing an inspiring, visionary speech.
Stops mid-speech, surprised by the echo, then quickly recovers and modifies his speech to be more impactful.
Does not thank Schaefer when prompted, showing a possible lack of social nicety or humility in professional interactions.

Bullies and screams at people during filming.
Pleases and seduces in interactions, showing emotional range.
Shows obsessive, demanding behavior, not patient with others.
Smiles slowly and says they're doing the project because it's going to be fun.

Leads the film production energetically, appearing everywhere at once, directing actors, adjusting props, rewriting the script, selecting costumes and camera angles, driving the project forward with obsessive intensity.
Bullies and screams at actors, exhibits demanding and sometimes harsh behavior while working on the set.
Repeats 'Again' many times to Paul Stewart to get the perfect take, causing Stewart to scream and collapse.
Smiles while acknowledging the difficulty and impossibility of adding ceilings to sets, showing determination but no explicit warmth.
Stands silently next to Toland after a camera crane accident that nearly injures Dorothy Commingore, showing no immediate reactive concern in the excerpt.
Insists on shooting multiple takes to get the perfect performance.

Spits in the electrician's face and orders him to get out.
Thunders 'STOP EVERYBODY STOP!' commanding immediate silence and attention on set.
Fiercely and purposefully spits in the electrician’s face and orders him off the set.
Watches scenes in screening room with feet up, exhausted but still engaged, showing awareness of the process.
Is relentless with Dorothy Commingore, driving her to intense performances off camera.

Rages at technical difficulties with lighting and deep-focus cross-fades, indicating frustration under pressure.
Grows increasingly manic and exhausted as pressure mounts, culminating in falling asleep with a smoldering cigar on his suit.
Apologizes and insists on pouring the tea himself, showing consideration for the scene and his co-actor.

Expresses vulnerability and regret by admitting confusion and wanting Mank back.
Offers Mank a shooting script as a gesture of reconciliation.

Smiles slowly despite tears, showing resilience and engagement.
Doing magic tricks for the cast.
Strutting, raging, boasting, dancing.

Shows intense passion and dedication to his vision, involving others in strenuous effort.

Continues to push actor despite signs of exhaustion and frustration, possibly risking morale and collaboration.
Shoves Joseph Cotton brutally and repeats the shove.
Encourages Joseph Cotton to confront the 'monster' with harsh truth.
Drinks to 'love on my own terms' with a mix of sincerity and defiance.
Acknowledges completion of the work quietly and with satisfaction.

Directs the scene to completion, calls 'Cut. Print' confidently, and savors the moment with satisfaction, indicating control and assurance.
Transitions smoothly from intense directing to casual camaraderie with the crew, showing social intelligence and self-assuredness.

Paces nervously before screening, worried about who attends and the quality of the film.

Is very particular about the music while scoring the picture, causing difficulty in scheduling a screening.
Shows dedication to his work by personally scoring the picture and being very particular about the music.

Succeeds in provoking strong reactions and pushback from powerful figures like Hearst and Louella, indicating the impact and ambition of his work.
Despite opposition, remains focused on releasing 'Citizen Kane' and navigating studio pressures, showing persistence and strategic awareness.
No direct dialogue or action shown in this excerpt, leading to ambiguity about his immediate responses or plans; some non-action could suggest lack of visible control in a tense environment.

Speaks simply and sincerely about freedom and the dangers of tyranny, appealing to shared values and the importance of voices in a free country.
